string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

search.slidetext: scenarios routines, rules and expectations the following scenarios demonstrate three different approachesto establishing routines, rules and expectations in the classroom. to access a scenario, select one of the year level buttons below,then use the arrow buttons on the bottom of the slide tonavigate the scenario. years f2 years f2 years f2 years f2 years f2 years f2 years 36 years 36 years 36 years 36 years 36 years 36 years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ years 7+ select a scenario to begin.

introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2 mx. j, a year 1 teacher, noticed that their students were struggling to transition from whole group instruction on the floor to working at their desks. students were making a lot of noise, wandering around the classroom, and taking a long time to resettle back at their desks. this was frustrating for mx. j as it wasted valuable learning time. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. scenario what should mx. j do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue.

introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. introduce a routine to help students transition from group to independent work. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up forlost learning time. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. reduce their expectations as the students are very young. scenario what should mx. j do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2 mx. j, a year 1 teacher, noticed that their students were struggling to transition from whole group instruction on the floor to working at their desks. students were making a lot of noise, wandering around the classroom, and taking a long time to resettle back at their desks. this was frustrating for mx. j as it wasted valuable learning time.

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. j knows that routines help students to be efficient and productive, reducing wasted learning time and helping to free up working memory to focus on learning. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

the routine included the following: a signal that it was time to transition mx. j used a bell to indicate that it was time to finish the floor activity and transition to the next task. when the bell was rung, students were cued to stop and look at the teacher for the next instruction. a quick stretch break mx. j acknowledged that students had been sitting on the floor for a period of time and asked them to stand up, make themselves as tall as they could and then shake out any stiffness. an opportunity to pack away materials if required, mx. j directed students to pack away materials and return to where they were standing on the floor. transition to desk mx. j reminded students of the three key behaviours they were watching for as students transitioned back to their desks: walk carefully and quietly sit down at desk get out any items needed for the need activity verbal and non-verbal acknowledgement mx. j used specific verbal praise (sam, i like the way you walked quietly to your desk, sat down and got your pencils out. nice job), and non-verbal acknowledgement such as smiling and a thumbs up, to reinforce the desired behaviour. select the blue x button above to close this routine. possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2 possible solution mx. j introduced the routine of transitioning from the floor to desks, explaining why the routine was important and what it should look and sound like. they then modelled and described the routine to their students and provided an opportunity for them to practise it with teacher support. scaffolds were slowly removed as appropriate, transferring ownership to their students. finally, mx. j had their students following the routine independently. the routine was retaught as required. click to see the full routine. full routine full routine full routine full routine page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

well done! this is a good solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the introduction button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! introduction introduction introduction introduction overall outcome mx. j noticed a significant improvement in their students' ability to transition from the floor to their desks within the first few days of explicitly teaching the routine. their students were more settled and ready to learn much more quickly. they noticed that the classroom was calmer, and they were spending more time teaching their students. mx. j believes that this approach to explicitly teaching the routine while providing the scaffolding needed to support the different needs of the students, was successful in creating a more efficient and productive classroom through reducing wasted learning time and helping students focus on their learning. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

context mx. j knows that learning time is valuable, and therefore students need to make up any learning time that is lost. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

possible solution mx. j decided that they would use a timer to time how long it took students to transition from the floor to their desks and settle down ready for work. the amount of time it took the students would be taken off time spent on preferred activities. during this time they would be expected to complete an independent literacy or maths based task. mx. j explained to the students the importance of learning time, and outlined their proposed plan. each time there was a transition from the floor to the table, mx. j would time the students anything more than two minutes was added to an ongoing tally on the board. this time was then made up when the class would normally be engaged in a preferred activity. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome mx. j realised this wasnt an efficient way of making up learning time as it was usually too short for any meaningful learning to happen, and so they would find themselves giving the students busy work. after some reflection, mx. j decided they needed to rethink their approach. at first, mx. j noticed an improvement in the time it was taking students to transition to their desks. however, after a couple of days, students started to fall back into their old patterns of behaviour, and students who were doing as they were asked were getting frustrated at missing out on their preferred activity because of the actions of others. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

context page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. j recognises that the students are young, and wonders if they are expecting too much from a group of year 1 students with a variety of educational and social needs. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mx. j decided to let things go and accept the fact that students would take some time to transition from the floor to their desks. they hoped that once the students got a little older and started to grow in maturity, they would start to transition in a more orderly way. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, mx. j was able to let go of their frustration and allow the students as much time as needed to transition to their desks. after a week, mx. j recognised that their frustration was started to surface again, as the time it was taking to transition was increasing, not decreasing, and valuable learning time was being lost. after some reflection, mx. j decided they needed to rethink their approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years f2

increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. ms. k, a year 5 teacher, faced challenges as her class struggled to follow the classroom rules. this negatively impacted teaching and learning time. the 10 existing rules were co-created with her students but were negative and did not align with the school values of respect, relationships and resilience. this led to resistance from students and a lack of clarity about what was expected of them. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. scenario what should ms. k do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. ms. k, a year 5 teacher, faced challenges as her class struggled to follow the classroom rules. this negatively impacted teaching and learning time. the 10 existing rules were co-created with her students but were negative and did not align with the school values of respect, relationships and resilience. this led to resistance from students and a lack of clarity about what was expected of them. what should ms. k do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reinforce the importance of learning time by getting students to make up for it. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. reflect upon the approach taken and do things differently. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

context ms. k knows that expectations help students to be efficient and productive, and that students who engage in unproductive behaviour need some form of consequence. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

possible solution ms. k outlines to her class the impact their behaviour is having on the teaching and learning in the classroom. she explains that she is going to enforce the expectations through increasing the use of consequences for unproductive behaviour. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome ms. k realised this wasnt an effective way of supporting the students to understand the expectations and engage with them. after some reflection, ms. k decided she needed to rethink her approach. ms. k noticed an immediate improvement in student behaviour, but it was short lived. students started to react against the consequences being imposed and pushed the boundaries even further. the classroom environment became more negative as ms. k was spending a significant amount of time handing out consequences rather than teaching. students who were not engaging in unproductive behaviour were missing out. ms. k noticed that she was getting more and more frustrated at the increased impact behaviour was having on learning, and was feeling exhausted and unmotivated. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

context ms. k knows that learning time is valuable, and therefore students need to make up any learning time that is lost. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

possible solution ms. k explained to the students the importance of learning time, and outlined her proposed plan. each time there was a period of unproductive behaviour, ms. k would time the students with minutes added to an ongoing tally on the board. this time was then made up when the class would normally be engaged in a preferred activity. ms. k decided she would use a timer to measure how long students were engaging in unproductive behaviour. the amount of time would be taken off time spent on preferred activities. during this time, students would be expected to complete an independent literacy or maths based task. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, ms. k noticed an improvement in the amount of time students spent productively. however, after a couple of days, students started to fall back into their old patterns of behaviour, and those who were doing as they were asked were getting frustrated at missing out on their preferred activity because of the actions of others. ms. k realised this wasnt an efficient way of making up learning time as it was usually too short for any meaningful learning to happen, and so she would find herself giving the students busy work. after some reflection, ms. k decided she needed to rethink her approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

context ms. k knows that understanding and following expectations helps students to be efficient and productive, reducing wasted learning time and helping to free up working memory to focus on learning. she completes a critical reflection on the approach she has taken. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

possible solution ms. k decided to work with the students to reduce the number of expectationsto 5, link them to the school values and reframe them in positive terms. she explicitly taught the expectations and provided additional scaffolding (such as visual cues and extra time for practise) for those students who required it. ms. k regularly monitored student behaviour to know when specific expectationsneeded to be retaught. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

well done! this is a good solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the introduction button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! introduction introduction introduction introduction overall outcome ms. k noticed a significant improvement in her class. students became more focused, calm, supportive and positive. they understood what was expected of them and why. the positive wording of the expectations and alignment with the school values created clarity and reduced student resistance. ms. k believes that this approach to reducing the number of expectations, positively framing them and having them linked to the school vales led to an improvement in student understanding. she can now see that explicitly teaching the expectations while providing the scaffolding needed to support the different needs of the students, was successful in creating a more productive classroom through reducing wasted teaching time and helping students focus on their learning. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 36

increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. have a colleague observe an afternoon class and provide feedback. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. mr. t, a year 7+ teacher, noticed that student behaviour was inconsistent throughout the day during his classes. he found afternoon classes were particularly prone to being unproductive, with students not following or meeting expectations, despite his best efforts. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress what should mr. t do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. have a colleague observe an afternoon class and provide feedback. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. mr. t, a year 7+ teacher, noticed that student behaviour was inconsistent throughout the day during his classes. he found afternoon classes were particularly prone to being unproductive, with students not following or meeting expectations, despite his best efforts. increase the use of negative consequences when students engage in unproductive behaviour. increase afternoon class and provide feedback. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. decrease expectations in afternoon classes and increase them in other classes. scenario please make a selection on the response to the situation to progress what should mr. t do to resolve this situation? select an option to explore the outcome. page 1 | 4 select a response to continue. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

context mr. t knows that expectations help students to be efficient and productive, and that students who engage in unproductive behaviour need some form of consequence. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

possible solution mr. t outlines to his afternoon classes the impact their behaviour is having on the teaching and learning. he explains that he is going to enforce the expectations through increasing the use of consequences for unproductive behaviour. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome mr. t noticed an immediate improvement in student behaviour, but it was short lived. students started to react against the consequences being imposed and pushed the boundaries even further. the classroom environment became more negative as mr. t was spending a significant amount of time handing out consequences rather than teaching. students who were not engaging in unproductive behaviour were missing out. mr. t noticed that he was getting more and more frustrated as the engagement with learning was decreasing even further, and he was feeling exhausted and unmotivated. mr. t realised this wasnt an effective way of supporting the students to understand the expectations and engage with them. after some reflection, mr. t decided he needed to rethink his approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

context mr. t knows that learning time is valuable, and therefore asked a colleague to observe his afternoon class and provide feedback. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

possible solution mr. t decided to implement changes to help maintain his stamina for the afternoon classes. he ensured he was well-hydrated throughout the day, ate a healthy lunch and took a break outside the classroom to recharge before the afternoon classes. mr. t also modelled and explicitly taught expectations to students again, reinforcing the expected behaviours. mr. ts colleague used a protocol to complete the observation and they met afterwards. the colleague suggested that what was missing was consistency in maintaining classroom behaviour expectations and suggested that mr. ts own fatigue was contributing to the problem. page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

introduction introduction introduction introduction well done! this is a good solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. or, you can select the introduction button below to close this scenario and select another year level to explore. well done! overall outcome mr. t's implementation of consistent classroom behaviour expectations positively impacted student behaviour. he found the afternoon classes were less disruptive and more focused on learning. by changing his habits and explicitly teaching the expectations, mr. t was able to re-establish a positive teaching and learning culture in the afternoon classes. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

context mr. t knows that learning time is valuable, but also understands that students may be feeling tired by the last class of the day. page 2 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

possible solution page 3 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. mr. t decided to reduce the expectations on students in the afternoon classes, and to work them harder during the lessons they had at other times of the day. he explained to the students this was the approach he was going to take. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+

this is not the best solution. select the blue x above to return to the beginning of the scenario and explore some other ways teachers might respond. overall outcome at first, mr. t noticed the students were responsive and grateful for the reduced expectations in the afternoon classes. however, after a couple of weeks, students started to push back against the increased expectations in the other classes. mr. t was spending increased amounts of time trying to persuade students to engage in learning activities and what was being produced was decreasing in quality. mr. t realised this wasnt an efficient way of making up learning time as it was putting unreasonable expectations onto students in the lessons that were not in the afternoon. after some reflection, mr. t decided he needed to rethink his approach. page 4 | 4 select the arrows to navigate. scenarios: routines, rules, and expectations | years 7+
